headline: Studies Suggest Why Omicron Is Less Severe: It Spares the Lungs
text: A spate of new studies on lab animals and human tissues are providing the first indication of why the Omicron variant causes milder disease than previous versions of the coronavirus.

headline: Virginia Sues Town of Windsor, Accusing It of Discriminatory Policing
text: Virginia’s attorney general filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the town of Windsor, seeking changes in policing and saying that his office’s monthslong investigation uncovered evidence of discriminatory, unconstitutional policing.

headline: The Secrets to Successful Aging in 2022
text: Looking for ways to grow old gracefully? Over the past year, Well’s columnists have reported on how to keep your mind and body healthy over time. Here are some of their top insights from the most popular stories published in 2021.

headline: Aiding Afghan Refugees in the U.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Decision Looms That Could Determine Fate of Alzheimer’s Drug
text: Federal officials are wrestling with a decision that could go a long way toward determining the future of the controversial new Alzheimer’s drug, Aduhelm, and whether significant numbers of patients use it.

headline: Why Did Uganda Send Troops Into Congo?
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — It has been a month since Uganda began air and artillery strikes in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and then sent in its troops, in an operation targeting a rebel group it accuses of carrying out a string of deadly attacks in the Ugandan capital, Kampala.

headline: Once a Janitor, Now the Bar Mitzvah Photography King of Montreal
text: MONTREAL — Braulio Rocha, a Portuguese janitor at a Montreal synagogue, was about to begin his daily floor mopping routine some years ago when he heard a frantic voice: The photographer assigned to shoot a bris, a ritual circumcision, hadn’t shown up, and the baby’s grandmother was panicking.

headline: China’s Ban on ‘Sissy Men’ Is Bound to Backfire
text: BEIJING — China is facing serious challenges on multiple fronts: Great power competition with the United States. Trade disputes. The future of Taiwan. But that doesn’t mean it’s too preoccupied to escalate a battle of another sort on the home front.

headline: Leadership Advice from the Coach of America’s ‘Worst’ Hockey Team
text: John Bacon got more satisfaction from coaching a bad hockey team than he did playing for a good one. In his new book, “Let Them Lead: Unexpected Lessons in Leadership from America’s Worst High School Hockey Team,” Bacon, a journalist and leadership consultant, explores why and what made the difference.

headline: Under the Radar Theater Festival Canceled as Omicron Surges
text: As a surge of coronavirus cases driven by the Omicron variant takes a growing toll on live performance, the Public Theater on Friday announced it would cancel its Under the Radar festival, originally scheduled to begin on Jan. 12.

headline: Earthy Mushrooms, Bold Peppers
text: Hello, Five Weeknight Dishers. This is Krysten, stepping in for Emily. (Close watchers of this space will remember me as this newsletter’s editor!)

headline: People with Omicron are less likely to need hospitalization, U.K. report finds.
text: LONDON — People who contracted the Omicron variant of the coronavirus were about half as likely to need hospital care as those infected with the Delta variant, and one-third as likely to need emergency care, according to a report issued on Friday by British health officials.

headline: Russian Foreign Minister Levels New Warning on Ukraine
text: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned on Friday that the Kremlin perceives the United States and its allies as stoking the war in eastern Ukraine, a shift in tone from Moscow just hours after another Russian official had said the Kremlin was satisfied with a phone call between the leaders of the two countries.

headline: A New Year and a New Leader, but Germany’s Focus Remains on Covid
text: HANOVER, Germany — There was a new face delivering the chancellor’s New Year’s Eve address, but for Covid-weary Germans, the focus was all too familiar.

headline: Quebec government faces backlash over New Year’s Eve curfew.
text: New Year’s Eve was canceled in Quebec, or at least that’s how many residents feel after the government imposed a 10 p.m. curfew that will go into effect on Friday night, just as the revelry was set to begin.

headline: The Times Square celebration will be muted. The police presence will not.
text: New York City prepared on Friday to welcome a new year with a heavily edited version of its traditional Times Square celebration.

headline: Sam Jones, Sharpshooting Celtics Star of the 1960s, Dies at 88
text: Sam Jones, the Boston Celtics’ sharpshooting Hall of Fame guard who played on 10 N.B.A. championship teams, a milestone exceeded only by his teammate Bill Russell, died on Thursday in Florida. He was 88.

headline: Omicron is overwhelming New York’s quarantine hotel system.
text: For much of the pandemic, one way New York City has tried to slow the coronavirus’s spread is by offering free hotel rooms to infected people who cannot easily isolate themselves from those they live with.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in January
text: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Betty White, a TV Fixture for Seven Decades, Is Dead at 99
text: Betty White, who created two of the most memorable characters in sitcom history, the nymphomaniacal Sue Ann Nivens on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and the sweet but dim Rose Nylund on “The Golden Girls” — and who capped her long career with a comeback that included a triumphant appearance as the host of “Saturday Night Live” at the age of 88 — died on Friday. She was 99.

headline: Vikings quarterback Kirk Cousins tests positive in latest blow to the N.F.L. postseason race.
text: Two days before the Minnesota Vikings face one of the best teams in the N.F.L., quarterback Kirk Cousins tested positive for the coronavirus and was placed on the team’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will sideline him for at least five days.

headline: What It’s Like to Leave Prison During a Pandemic
text: For most people, patching together a life after prison is a daunting task. Even getting an ID can be tricky. We spent a year with Richard, Genisis and Mychal as they navigated the transition from cell to home.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Welcome. It’s New Year’s Eve and Omicron has put the brakes on any socially proximate revelry we may have had planned. We’re old pros by now at re-envisioning holidays — we’re old pros at re-envisioning any day, truth be told.

headline: Public university students in New York must now get vaccine boosters.
text: Nearly 600,000 public university students in New York will soon be required to get vaccination booster shots as part of the state’s stepped-up effort to combat a record-breaking coronavirus outbreak, Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday.
